Sustainability can mean starting from scratchâ€”but more often, itâ€™s about analyzing and reimagining what we already have.

Take for example, our MRI systems where an upgraded cold head can mean using far less helium or a refurbished scanner can be carefully restored to serve patients for years to come. Another example is our lab diagnostic systems. These workhorses often run nonstop in busy hospital labs and, after years of heavy use, can be rigorously restored with the latest hardware and software to perform like new.

These quieter forms of innovation are powerful. Not only do they extend the life of critical technology, they also reduce waste and preserve precious resources. Itâ€™s progressâ€”not by replacement, but by renewal.

Equally inspiring is the craftsmanship behind it: Engineers who design smarter ways to trap and reuse helium. Teams who recalibrate systems with precision and care. Their work isnâ€™t always seen, but the impact is felt in every scan delivered without delay and in every patient diagnosis made possible.

At, we believe sustainability starts with design, but lives in the details. That sometimes, a systemâ€™s â€œend of lifeâ€ is really just the start of a better one.

Siemens Healthineers has made a strong start to the second half of the year. We had a very good quarter with high revenue growth, another increase in profitability, and strong free cash flow. Our revenue rose by 7.6% on a comparable basis to just under â‚¬5.7 billion. The Imaging andsegments, in particular, contributed to this very strong revenue development. Equipment order intake clearly exceeded equipment revenue. The equipment book-to-bill ratio was good, at 1.09.

While volatility in the geopolitical environment remains high, our performance shows the value of our healthcare innovations for more and more patients around the world. As a result of the latest geopolitical developments, in particular the agreements on trade tariffs, we narrow the ranges for comparable revenue growth and adjusted basic earnings per share in our outlook for fiscal year 2025. We also raise the midpoints of the ranges, mainly due to our performance year to date.

We win as
together with our customers and partners. Jointly â€“ and often over years and decades â€“ we fight serious illnesses such as heart disease, stroke, cancer, and dementia. Over the past few weeks, I have had the opportunity to meet some of our partners to mark some special occasions. We strengthened our relationships further and are making good progress in the task of taking the fear out of the most threatening diseases: Firstly, by working tirelessly on new technologies and improving existing solutions. Secondly, by making these technologies and solutions accessible to more and more people.

Because this is our purpose: pioneering breakthroughs in healthcare â€“ for everyone, everywhere, sustainably. Thank you,
, for bringing it to life every day!

In fighting the most threatening illnesses, we are focusing on the so-called "hidden pandemics" caused by non-communicable diseases. These diseases are responsible for almost three quarters of all deaths each year. We do not want to accept this.

We believe that everyone has the right to the highest attainable standard of health. We want to make a strong contribution with our customers and partners around the world. In this new episode of ourShape 25 Spotlight, we therefore take a joint look at latest developments and best practices in
care.

Many thanks to our customers Prof. Richard Booton, MD, from, UK, and, MD, from Hospital Haroldo JuaÃ§aba, Brazil, for sharing their insights with us. A very special thanks goes to their courageous patients who contributed very personal, hopeful stories to this episode. ğŸ’ªğŸ™

By joining our forces, we are working towards a world without fear of cancer. Click here to watch the new episode:

Across Europe, weâ€™re honored to work with some of the most respected and forward-looking hospitals and health systems. Many of these relationships go back decades, having been built on a shared commitment to advancing healthcare not just within national borders, but also on a global scale. With roots in Europe ourselves, we athave appreciated how these close partnerships continue to inspire the breakthroughs we work on every day.

Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m delighted to share that weâ€™ve signed a new research agreement with(GSD), a long-standing partner and Italyâ€™s largest healthcare provider. Our primary goal: to establish advanced imaging technologies, such as photon-counting CT, as an integral part of personalized medicine.

Together with GSDâ€™sin Milan, we will develop post-processing software for the automated analysis of photon-counting CT images, with a special focus on lung and cardiovascular imaging. At the same time, we will explore the organizational and economic impacts of introducing such technology within hospital settings.

This agreement not only strengthens our relationship and sets the stage for meaningful progress in healthcare delivery â€” it also completes a major milestone. With this signing, we are now partnering with all members of theon scientific projects. Ospedale San Raffaele represents the final piece of the puzzle, and their trust in us underscores the depth of collaboration weâ€™ve built across the alliance.

A big thank you to the GSD and GKSD leaders and their teams who joined us today for this special occasion: President Dr. Kamel Ghribi, Marco Centenari,,,, Prof., and Prof..

Thank you also to,,, and our many
colleagues for making this ongoing collaboration possible.

I had the pleasure of joining Nic Encina on the ğ˜¶ğ˜¯ğ˜•ğ˜¢ğ˜µğ˜¶ğ˜³ğ˜¢ğ˜­ ğ˜šğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜¦ğ˜¤ğ˜µğ˜ªğ˜°ğ˜¯ podcastâ€”a name that couldnâ€™t be more fitting for a conversation about how we ğ˜¤ğ˜©ğ˜°ğ˜°ğ˜´ğ˜¦ to shape the future of healthcare. The episode just went live today (link is in the comments), and I invite you to listen and share your thoughts.

Nic and I talked about the patient needs and customer impact that drive what we do at. From digitalization and AI to our companyâ€™s transformative combination with, weâ€™re working to redefine the next era of healthcare where diagnostics, data, and therapy converge into intelligent systems to better address non-communicable diseases (NCDs) in a more precise, human-centered way.

Thank you, Nic, for the thoughtful questions and the opportunity to reflect on whatâ€™s next for Siemens Healthineers as we pioneer breakthroughs for everyone, everywhere, sustainably.

A year ago, I visited our long-standing partner Stroke International Services (S.I.S.) in Vietnam's Mekong Delta. It was an impressive experience â€“ not just because of the unforgettable ride on their ambulance speed boat:... Most importantly, we agreed at the time to expand our existing collaboration. Now we were able to return the hospitality and welcome S.I.S. to Germany.

We are taking the next step in this Value Partnership, built on mutual trust and our shared vision for innovation: S.I.S. andwill further pioneer breakthroughs in
in the Mekong Delta and across
through advanced technologies like NAEOTOM Alpha and ARTIS Icono. Together, we will enhance patient experience and care outcomes in stroke and cardiac services, ensure sustainability and clinical excellence, and create a platform for training and knowledge exchange, connecting Vietnamese clinicians with regional and global experts. Thus, we are pleased to establish S.I.S. Can Tho as a
Global Training Center.

I would like to thank the S.I.S. team for the fruitful talks and their trust in our performance. We very much value the responsibility and are proud to support S.I.S. in its mission to be the "Savior for Stroke Patients".

At Siemens Healthineers, itâ€™s not always about uncovering the unknown. Often, itâ€™s about making what we already see more preciseâ€”and more accessible to those who need it most.

Take Cinematic Reality, portrayed in one of the background images on my profile. It marks a shift from flat, grayscale slices to vivid 3D visualizations where anatomy takes on depth, texture, and life-like detail. These immersive, interactive holograms are created directly from real patient data and allow clinicians to explore the human body in entirely new ways.

They can rotate a heart in virtual space, trace the nervous system, or examine a tumor from every angle. Itâ€™s not just visually stunning; itâ€™s clinically valuable and offers a lot of potential: Surgeons can plan more precisely. Students can learn more intuitively. Patients can receive care thatâ€™s more personalized, more informed. I find this so inspiring because when we see with greater clarity, we can care with greater confidence.

Sometimes the most beautiful breakthroughs arenâ€™t just what we see, but how we see.

#Run4Healthineers | Itâ€™s a summer tradition many of us look forward to. Each year, my colleagues in Germany and I enthusiastically lace up our sneakers, print out our race numbers, and get moving for a good cause.

I wanted to make sure to join in even though business travels took me to Cleveland, Ohio, on the day of the event. It felt special to log in my kilometers here, on a route that took me by buildings of two of our great collaboration partners:and/. I was delighted to representwhile exploring more of what this city has to offer.

For every colleague who ran, walked, hiked, or cycled at the event in person or remotely, we will donate to local charitable organizations in Erlangen and Forchheim, Germany. Thank you to all who took part and contributed! You make a difference.

What an honor to be in Cleveland, Ohio, celebrating 40 years of partnership with Case Western Reserve University, a collaboration that began just two years after MRI technology became available. 

Itâ€™s great reconnecting with renowned experts and colleagues to reflect on how far weâ€™ve come since installing our first clinical system there. When we first started working together, many of the applications we rely on today were still on the horizon. Scans were slow, the experience for patients was often uncomfortable, and image quality was a far cry from what we expect now.

Together, we were motivated by the possibilities to shape this field and so, we started pushing boundaries early on. For example, our work on real-time MRI in the 80s helped lay the groundwork for what we now know as minimally invasive, image-guided procedures. These helped make interventions safer and patient recovery times shorter. Then, thanks to various breakthroughs in the following decades, 3D imaging became reality, scans got faster and more precise, and images became clearer and more detailed.

Because of contributions from partnerships like ours, MRI turned into what we know today: a quicker, more comfortable experience for patients, and a powerful and versatile tool for providers to screen, diagnose, and treat with confidence. Itâ€™s been an exciting journey of transforming ğ›ğ¨ğ¥ğ ideas into solutions used around the world. In many ways, weâ€™re just getting started. Weâ€™re already exploring whatâ€™s next in precision imaging, AI-driven workflows, and scaling innovations across entire fleets of scanners.

A heartfelt congratulations to the team of experts at Case Western andwho have made these 40 years so meaningful. Your camaraderie, curiosity, and brilliance are behind every breakthrough and the reasons this partnership continues to move forward and deliver real impact for patients and communities.

Thank you,,,,,,,,,,,... your teams, and so many more!

Wir werden in der
nicht nur zusammen forschen, sondern klinische MaÃŸnahmen auch schnellstmÃ¶glich in die Praxis umsetzen. Wir starten damit in der Kardiologie, denn Herz-Kreislauf-Erkrankungen sind die hÃ¤ufigste Todesursache in Deutschland. Damit wollen wir uns nicht abfinden. Mit neuen Bildgebungs-Techniken und KI-basierten Werkzeugen, um diese Bilder auszuwerten, kÃ¶nnen wir Patienten schneller und gezielter behandeln â€“ im besten Fall, bevor eine Krankheit entsteht und Schaden anrichtet. Damit verbessern wir nicht nur die LebensqualitÃ¤t von vielen Menschen, sondern helfen auch, Gesundheitskosten zu senken.

Ich freue mich daher sehr Ã¼ber diese neue Kooperation: Sie ist eine gute Nachricht fÃ¼r Patienten, Mediziner und unser Gesundheitssystem.

Back in January at the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting, I sat down with Linda Lacina for a conversation on the â€œMeet The Leaderâ€ podcast â€” a thoughtful exchange that just went live.

We talked about a special initiative to expand access to stroke care in Vietnam, the role of AI in closing health equity gaps, and how lessons from physics and basketball continue to shape my work and perspectives.

This particular clip touches on something weâ€™re always working to improve at: how we support care providers in navigating todayâ€™s biggest healthcare challenges â€” from staff shortages to rising costs to the growing burden of noncommunicable diseases. Itâ€™s about being a trusted technology partner, yes, but also someone who can help connect the dots and look at the big picture. You can find the full episode in the comments.

Thank you, Linda and the team at WEF, for the invitation and the engaging conversation.

Ich erinnere mich noch gut als meine (heute erwachsenen) Kinder noch Kinder oder Teenager waren und welchen SpaÃŸ ich hatte, ihnen bei unseren Sommerfesten zu zeigen, was fÃ¼r ein fantastisches Unternehmen wir sind, an was fÃ¼r spannenden Projekten ich arbeite und mit was fÃ¼r interessanten, witzigen und coolen Leuten ich zusammenarbeite. Heute habe ich die â€nÃ¤chste Generationâ€œ von Kindern und Teenagern gesehen, die, genau wie meine damals, ganz genau hingeschaut und hingehÃ¶rt haben, um zu verstehen, was Mama und Papa meinen, wenn sie â€von der Arbeitâ€œ sprechen.
und jeder und jede von uns haben sich in den vergangenen Jahren verÃ¤ndert und weiterentwickelt: Geblieben ist die Freude und der Stolz auf das, was wir tun.

fÃ¶rdert Freiwilligenarbeit und soziale Verantwortung auf der ganzen Welt: Von StrandsÃ¤uberungsaktionen in Indonesien Ã¼ber Hilfe und Begleitung von Eltern und schwerkranken Kindern in China bis zur UnterstÃ¼tzung der Special Olympics in Bayern.

Wir verstehen Freiwilligenarbeit einerseits als Teil unserer Verpflichtung gegenÃ¼ber den Gesellschaften in den LÃ¤ndern, in denen wir aktiv sind, andererseits ist sie fÃ¼r uns ein wichtiges Element unserer Kultur und unseres Zusammenhalts im Unternehmen.

Some innovations look like high-tech marvels. Others are shaped by handâ€”in fire, with skill passed down through generations.

X-ray technology has advanced in leaps: faster scans, sharper images, greater reliability. But at the heart of every X-ray tube lies a centuries-old craft that still matters today: glassblowing.

In Rudolstadt, Germany, our artisans form the delicate glass components for X-ray tubes by hand. Each piece must withstand extreme heat and pressure, while meeting incredible precision standards. Thereâ€™s no automation for this level of craftsmanshipâ€”just expertise, care, and consistency.

Why does it matter? Because the reliability of these components helps bring diagnostic care to more people, in more placesâ€”from hospitals to mobile clinics in remote regions. Itâ€™s a reminder that even the most advanced technology depends on people. On craft. On detail.

This is what I love about our work: the intersection of deep tradition and modern impact.

Not all our breakthroughs in medical technology look like a big machine. Sometimes itâ€™s a small vialâ€”filled with a few teaspoons of bloodâ€”that carries the potential to change a life.

Take multiple sclerosis (MS), a disease that affects nearly 3 million people worldwide. For many, the wait for symptoms to appear, or for imaging to confirm what they already feel, can be full of uncertainty. Now a simple blood test can deliver key insights and help ensure patients get the right care at the right time. I find this quiet breakthrough so powerful.

The test targets neurofilament light chain (NfL), a blood-based biomarker now detectable with a diagnostic test. This is the first CE-marked* biomarker for MS. When used together with other clinical, imaging, and laboratory findings, NfL can help predict the risk of MS disease activity in an individual patient with RMS. These earlier insights help clinicians personalize treatment earlier and give the patient something often missing: clarity.

Itâ€™s not dramatic on the outside, but the impact is very real. This is the kind of innovation I believe deserves more attentionâ€”the kind that puts meaningful change in a small vial.

Eine offene und intensive Diskussion zu den Themen unserer Zeit, die MÃ¶glichkeit dazulegen, was Siemens Healthineers bewegt und wofÃ¼r wir stehen und eine spannende FÃ¼hrung durch die Studios des Bayrischen Rundfunks. Ganz herzlichen Dank,,, und Torsten Teichmann fÃ¼r die Einladung zum Redaktionsbesuch am wunderschÃ¶nen BR-Standort NÃ¼rnberg!

Much of what fuels innovation in healthcare stays behind the scenes (or behind the lab). Itâ€™s not always the news of the moment, but itâ€™s the foundation of who we are and what I find fascinating and worth sharing. Iâ€™m always astonished by how far weâ€™ve come as a team, and excited by the pace at which weâ€™re changing what will be possible tomorrow. So why not shine a light on some of the overlooked detailsâ€”or, better yet, the quiet breakthroughs that make all the difference?

Each background picture on my profile has its own story to tell. Yes, as a physicist and a Healthineer, I may be a bit biased. But I think many would agree: thereâ€™s a lot of art in science. And the details are often extraordinary.

Take photon-counting CT, for example. To pioneer breakthroughs like this, we now grow crystalsâ€”cadmium telluride, to be exactâ€”over 12 intense weeks. In nature, the same process would take millions of years. The purest cadmium telluride crystal is the starting point for a quantum leap in computed tomography technology. Years of research, development, and production have led to the creation of pure crystals with electrical properties that have revolutionized CT detector technology.

Yes, itâ€™s technical. But the impact is very human.

Every touchpoint matters. Because these carefully grown crystals help deliver sharper insights, earlier answers, and better outcomes for everyone, everywhere, sustainably.

This is just one glimpse behind the curtain. What do you think about this one? Iâ€™ll be sharing what catches my attention from each background soon!

This is good news for patients and physicians everywhere in the world, especially in underserved regions: The World Health Assembly, the decision-making body of the World Health Organization, approved a resolution to strengthen medical imaging capacity. ğŸ©»ğŸš€

In a nutshell: This resolution addresses the issue of global equity in access to imaging, recognizing that medical imaging is vital for the diagnosis and treatment of numerous diseases, injuries and other health conditions. Thus, it urges the WHO member states "to promote appropriate and continued access to quality, safe, affordable and cost-effective medical imaging capacity, by implementing appropriate policies, strategies, programmes, norms and standards".

While the decisions of the World Health Assembly are not legally binding, they carry significant political and strategic influence. We atwelcome this decision wholeheartedly and with great confidence in its added value for patients. We stand ready to support our customers and partners in its implementation. Its essence precisely captures the purpose of our company that drives us every day: We pioneer breakthroughs in healthcare â€“ for everyone, everywhere, sustainably.

ğ—™ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—±ğ—²ğ—°ğ—®ğ—±ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ—¯ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¸ğ˜ğ—µğ—¿ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—´ğ—µğ˜€. Today we celebrate 50 years of Computed Tomography at Siemens Healthineers. For me personally, it has been an absolute privilege to experience more than half of that journey so far, seeing how our progress and pioneering role in CT exemplify what our company stands for.

I joined the CT team as a product manager 26 years ago, right after we launched our newest innovation at the time: multislice CT technology with the SOMATOM Volume Zoom. Multislice took CT to another level, starting to transform the cross-sectional imaging (essentially, a 2D paradigm) into producing an "isotropic 3D copy" of the patient. A universe of new clinical applications opened up: from metastasis screening to vascular imaging to the first CT images of the coronaries. And viewing slices like on a film sheet, turned into browsing in the "3D copy" of the patient with the first post-processing applications.

Making these breakthroughs available for everyone everywhere quickly became our target and within just one decade, all of our CT scanners, even in the entry level, had multislice technology inside.

Among the things our CT team is exemplary for all Healthineers: the team constantly thinks ahead, never resting on their laurels. Even amid the "Slice Wars" in the early 2000s, they were already at work on the revolutionary dual-source CT technology while simultaneously starting the photon-counting project and becoming the frontrunner in AI applications. Their enduring mindset has driven incredible advances in cardiovascular imaging and in diagnosing cancer, stroke, and lung disease. CT has become so widely used across many cases that itâ€™s now an essential tool in clinical settings like the emergency room and radiotherapy planning â€“ the latter being elementary in our successful combination with.

As for photon-counting CTâ€¦ We â€“ and more importantly, many of our customers â€“ are convinced itâ€™s set to become the standard for CT in the future. It has the potential to be a true catalyst in preventive healthcare, helping to detect diseases earlier and creating an almost digital twin of the patient. With that level of insight, clinicians can make faster and more personalized decisions on the next step for their patient.

We were the first to introduce the photon-counting CT scanner in 2021. Our focus has since shifted to a bigger question: how can we ensure everyone, everywhere truly benefits from this technology? Just as we were the fastest to make multislice CT accessible to all, our ambition now is to positively impact 1 billion lives over the next decade by bringing photon-counting CT within reach of more communities.

We got to this point because of the dedication, vision, and hard work of
and â€“ as importantly â€“ through the inspiration, collaboration, trust, and scientific brilliance of our partners in clinical research in medical institutions worldwide. Thank you!

Reflecting on my brief but meaningful visit to Poland this week, one thing is clear: the capital city of Warsaw is emerging as a destination for healthcare excellence, particularly for the youngest patients needing specialized care and for providers honing their diagnostics skills.

Atin Warsaw, it was a privilege to meet with the experts making remarkable progress in researching and treating the most complex and challenging pediatric cases. Their commitment to enhancing â€“ and saving â€“ these young lives is truly inspiring, and we are honored that they have long been aGlobal Pediatric Reference Center. CHMI is also an important scientific collaboration partner of ours, with cooperation going beyond the country to the CEECA regional level. Some recent collaboration projects include using brain scans to better understand how multiple sclerosis develops, testing different PET scans to find where seizures begin in children with epilepsy, and finding ways to make MRI scans less stressful for adolescents (and their parents). Thank you, Dr. Marek MigdaÅ‚, Prof. ElÅ¼bieta Jurkiewicz, Prof. Bozenna Dembowska-Baginska, and Dr. Anna ÅšliwiÅ„ska for your time and the great exchange between our teams!

While collaboration with our scientific partners fuels innovation, itâ€™s hands-on training and education for technicians and clinicians that bring that innovation to life in everyday healthcare. The experts at the ğ—¦ğ—¶ğ—²ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—›ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¹ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—²ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ—”ğ—°ğ—®ğ—±ğ—²ğ—ºğ˜† in Warsaw play a key role in this effort, offering specialized master classes, many of them peer-to-peer, across all diagnostic modalities. I was happy to finally set foot in the Academy and personally thank the hard-working team that has trained more than 27,000 radiologists and other healthcare professionals from Poland and abroad over the last nine years.

A big thanks also toand the entire
Poland for your warm welcome and lively dialogues. You are making a difference for your customers and the patients they serve â€“ keep up the terrific work!

Siemens Healthineers has been deeply connected to Poland for a long time â€“ building strong partnerships and collaborating with providers to pioneer breakthroughs for everyone, everywhere, sustainably. Yesterday, I had the honor to meet with, Dr., Prof.and their team atand explore how we can take that progress even further.

As Polandâ€™s leader in the private healthcare sector, Lux Med is big on operational efficiency and improving the patient experience across their 300 clinics and hospitals. They are rethinking how technology drives smarter planning and are putting AI to work to empower their teamsâ€”so that the 2.5 million patients that come through their doors each year can get better, faster, and more personalized care.

For example, we are pleased to already support them with AI solutions in radiology. It was fantastic to learn about the positive impact so far, especially how theyâ€™ve managed to accelerate MRI scans with the aid of our AI-powered image reconstruction technology â€“ something weâ€™ve been hearing consistently from other adopters. Soon, Lux Med will also integrate our remote scanning capabilities to help improve local access to advanced imaging while addressing the ongoing workforce shortage of technologists.

Thank you again to the entire Lux Med team for your hospitality and motivating discussions. Weâ€™re excited to continue working with you.

Zu meinen schÃ¶nsten Privilegien als CEO von Siemens Healthineers gehÃ¶rt es, mich mit jungen Menschen aus der ganzen Welt Ã¼ber ihre Ziele und Ideen zu unterhalten. Viele von ihnen stehen am Anfang ihrer Karriere und wollen wissen, wie das bei mir damals war. Besonders hÃ¤ufig kommen diese drei Fragen. Vielleicht hilft es ja jemandem, wenn ich sie hier einmal gesammelt beantworte â€“ ohne Anspruch auf AllgemeingÃ¼ltigkeit.

ğŸš€ "Wie war der Start in dein Berufsleben?"

Ich habe nach meiner Promotion in Theoretischer Physik bei Siemens angefangen. Aber es hat etwas gedauert, bis ich dort den richtigen Platz fÃ¼r mich gefunden hatte. Doch mit dem VerstÃ¤ndnis fÃ¼r die ZusammenhÃ¤nge von Medizin, Technik, Wirtschaft und Gesundheit wuchs dann auch die Begeisterung immer mehr. Ich weiÃŸ noch sehr genau, wie ich plÃ¶tzlich morgens ohne Wecker aufgewacht bin, weil ich unbedingt wieder loslegen wollte, weil mich meine Aufgabe und die Menschen dort so fasziniert haben.

ğŸ§  "Wer war â€“ oder ist â€“ dein Vorbild?"

Ich glaube, dass man von jedem Menschen etwas lernen kann. Das ist das SchÃ¶ne an diversen, internationalen Teams, wo jedes Mitglied einen anderen Hintergrund und andere Erfahrungen mitbringt. Besonders gerne erinnere ich mich aber an Professor Erich Reinhardt, damals Bereichsvorstand fÃ¼r die Medizintechnik bei Siemens. Er hat uns beigebracht, wie man richtig streitet. Das beste Argument zÃ¤hlt, nicht wer es vorbringt. "Wir brauchen eine Streitkultur, keinen Harmonieterror", hat er oft gesagt. Und damit hat er das Unternehmen, das ich jetzt fÃ¼hren darf, bis heute geprÃ¤gt.

ğŸ½ï¸ "Hast du ein Rezept fÃ¼r beruflichen Erfolg?"

Ich habe kein Rezept, aber vielleicht einen Rat. In der RÃ¼ckschau sehe ich meinen Weg als eine Verkettung glÃ¼cklicher ZufÃ¤lle. Aber diese ZufÃ¤lle mÃ¼ssen schon auf eine gute Vorbereitung treffen, damit sie auch wirken kÃ¶nnen. Ich glaube, fÃ¼r junge Menschen ist es wichtig, sich verschiedene Dinge anschauen zu kÃ¶nnen. So findet man heraus, was einen wirklich begeistert. Das Leben ist zu kurz, um Dinge zu tun, die man nicht liebt. Und dann wird man auch nicht gut darin. As a Berliner by choice, many of the city's monuments remind me time and again of the brutalities of war and Nazi terror: from the Holocaust Memorial to the destroyed Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church and the site honoring victims of the Nazi euthanasia program. These are depressing places. Not suppressing the crimes and horrors, but remembering them in the midst of our diverse, vibrant, pulsating capital today gives hope: never again!

80 years ago today, the Second World War ended and with it, the Nazi regime. Together with 47 other German companies, we therefore want to pay respects to the victims of this dark chapter in our countryâ€™s history. At the same time, we would like to remember the hope that the end of the war brought to Europe and the world. International cohesion, the rule of law, and freedom are achievements that we must protect together.

Our democracy is precious, it thrives on participation, courage and dissent. It also requires effort and many compromises, but in return it gives us peace, security and prosperity â€“ and provides us with the strength to stand up for others who are threatened by war, terror, and persecution today. We stand by our responsibility: not only out of a historical obligation, but out of deep human conviction.

With Easter and perhaps a spring vacation just around the corner, you may be looking for some food for thought. I'd like to recommend three eye-opening 
hashtag
#books that explore human nature with a sense of 
hashtag
#hope â€“ both through
and personal narrative.

ğŸ“– "The Righteous Mind" (2012) by Jonathan Haidt:

I greatly admire's work and recently had the privilege of meeting him at the WEF 2025. Jonathan is a social psychologist at the. "The Righteous Mind" is not his most recent book, but a bestseller that offers explanations for many questions driving society and politics today. How does social polarization develop? Why do we have such different moral perceptions of justice, freedom, and authority? Why are we individuals on the one hand and enjoy being part of groups on the other? And what is this built-in "PR agency" that justifies our actions to others?

ğŸ“– "Blueprint: The Evolutionary Origins of a Good Society" (2019) by Nicholas A. Christakis:

Another bestseller, another deep dive into our DNA, minds and societies:is a social scientist and physician atwhose work focuses on network science and biosocial science. His book "Blueprint" really resonated with me, in showing that our ability to build fair, cooperative communities is hardwired into our DNAâ€”it's human nature, not just ideology. It helped me see why many utopian visions fail: they overlook the social structures we're biologically built to form. The book highlights the common ground we all share. In times of division, I found "Blueprint" to be a refreshing take on the idea that the drive to build inclusive, connected communities isnâ€™t politicalâ€”it's human.

ğŸ“– "VaterlÃ¤nder" (2024) by Sabin Tambrea:

Sabin Tambrea is a German actor with Romanian roots. His German novel "VaterlÃ¤nder" draws from real events and his familyâ€™s personal experiences. It's an incredibly sensitive and moving book, in which the author tells how the communist dictatorship in Romania under Nicolae CeauÈ™escu oppressed three generations of his family and caused them immense sufferingâ€”leading to their escape and a fresh start in Germany. It made me reflect on utopias, on why dictatorships can persist for so longâ€”and it offers a lot of hope through its humanity.

Every evening, people came to their windows and applauded healthcare professionals. This was a mass phenomenon five years ago, but now, it may be one of those strange lockdown behaviors we have gradually forgotten.

Yet as time goes on, itâ€™s important to keep in mind that healthcare depends on the resilience, skill, and dedication of its people. Growing workloads and increasing demands make it harder for healthcare professionals to deliver care and find satisfaction in their work. To ensure a sustainable future, we must create workplaces where healthcare professionals feel valued, supported, and equipped with the right skills and technology to thrive.

At, we explore ways to empower todayâ€™s workforce â€“ and make a career in healthcare deeply fulfilling.

Many thanks to our customers,, Prof. Jonathan A. Ripp, MD, andfor sharing their insights and learnings with us.

John Kowal will succeed David Pacitti, as President and Head of the Americas at Siemens Healthineers effective April 14, 2025. Dave will assume the position of Chief Executive Officer at Avanos Medical, effective April 14.

Under Daveâ€™s leadership, the Americas region significantly contributed to the company's success, establishing us as a leading MedTech company in the United States. One of the highlights of his contributions over the last decade is the creation and expansion of our strategic value partnerships in the U.S. Dave: On behalf of the entire Siemens Healthineers team, I would like to extend my sincere gratitude for your dedication, passion, and many contributions to our company. We wish you the very best in your new role.

Congratulations, John Kowal on your new appointment as President and Head of Siemens Healthineers Americas. Your 20 years of tenure in Varian has been instrumental in advancing its mission of â€œa world without fear of cancerâ€. Through your unwavering commitment to our customers, you have delivered outstanding business results for Varian and subsequently for Siemens Healthineers. I have full confidence in your ability to even further strengthen the value proposition of our combination for our customers and their patients. I am very much looking forward to having you join our leadership team and working with you in the years ahead.

Fifteen years ago, I had the privilege of being a participant in the Baden-Badener Unternehmer GesprÃ¤che e.V. (BBUG), preparing for increasingly responsible roles alongside amazing peers from companies across various industries. Today, after more than 10 years as CEO of, I had the honor and pleasure of speaking to those who are now preparing for their own future leadership roles, having been nominated by their companies.

I always greatly enjoy moments like theseâ€”they are enriching, offering fresh perspectives and thought-provoking questions. Plus, simply explaining oneâ€™s own work helps sharpen oneâ€™s own thinking.

Of course, there was a lot to share at the beginning: about non-communicable diseases (cancer, cardiovascular disease, stroke, etc.), which we are dedicated to combating; about access to care for 8 billion people; and about the shortage of healthcare professionals among our customers. We also discussed our IPO, the combination with, the central role of AI in our products, the path to groundbreaking innovations like Photon-Counting CT, and our Value Partnerships with leading customers.

The discussion that followed was lively and engaging, conducted under Chatham House Rulesâ€”which is why I summarize the following seven key takeaways:

1ï¸âƒ£ We should not see healthcare spending as a cost but as an investment in a better life.
2ï¸âƒ£ The healthcare industry is a vital yet often underestimated part of a country's economic value creation.
3ï¸âƒ£ Medical technology is an exciting "dialogue discipline" where progress is only possible through deep mutual understanding between medical professionals and engineers. This is fascinatingâ€”but also teaches humility.
4ï¸âƒ£ Our IPO allowed us to create a much more focused company, entirely dedicated to our specific customer base, and to reinvent ourselves. I am deeply grateful for that. And only through the IPO the combination with Varian was possible, for example.
5ï¸âƒ£ Progress always moves in two directions: Improving what already exists and creating access where it was previously unaffordable.For example, digitalization initially digitizes what was analog, but "digital first" solutions bypass analog altogether, making things possible for the first time. Many medical breakthroughs follow the same principle.
6ï¸âƒ£ Right now, we talk a lot about managing change in the world. My advice: from time to time, consciously reflect on what does NOT change and what always holds true.
7ï¸âƒ£ And lastly: Take good care of your own health and your relationships.

Thank you,, for the invitation, and thank you to all the participants for the fantastic discussion!

Our Annual Shareholdersâ€™ Meeting 2025 has just concluded. We looked back on our successes in fiscal year 2024, where we once more achieved our ambitious targets despite the difficult economic environment. Thus, our shareholders approved a dividend of EUR 0.95 per share, as proposed by the Supervisory Board and the Managing Board. Our results of the first quarter of fiscal year 2025 show that our performance is consistently improving from a high base.

The relevance ofis not solely reflected in financial metrics. It is also defined by the lives we impact. In 2024, patients around the world interacted with our products and solutions a total of 2.6 billion times â€“ a remarkable number, and each of these â€œPatient Touchpointsâ€ involves a human story. Ambitious to do even more, we have set ourselves the target of increasing our Patient Touchpoints to 3.3 billion by 2030.

At the same time, more and more customers are deciding to shape their future together with us: As of today, we have entered into Value Partnerships with around 200 institutions in more than 40 countries. The total value of orders on hand from these partnerships stands at approximately EUR 5 billion. Our Value Partnerships are not limited to private and public healthcare providers; we are also making agreements with more and more regional and national governments.

Together with our customers and partners, we are fighting the most threatening illnesses: Non-communicable diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular disease, stroke, and dementia that are responsible for almost three quarters of all deaths. Our efforts revolve around fighting these diseases by utilizing our strengths in precision therapy, patient twinning, digitalization, data, and AI. The success of our business and the opportunity to work in a highly essential industry makes us a very attractive employer â€“ and we intend to remain one of the best in our sector.

We appreciate the ongoing trust of our Supervisory Board, shareholders, customers, partners, and employees, whose commitment and passion are vital to our purpose of pioneering breakthroughs in healthcare for everyone, everywhere, sustainably. â€“ Thank you!

Tomorrow, Tuesday, we are inviting our investors to the Annual Shareholders' Meeting 2025. We have just successfully completed the dress rehearsal. It has almost become a tradition to have a group of apprentices and dual students fromlook over our shoulders â€“ and take a look behind the complex scenes. We naturally want to encourage their curiosity, because young talents are the future of our company.

Last year, over 200 young people started their apprenticeship or dual study program with us. For 2025, we have again advertised over 200 positions, spread across 16 different programs. As of today, around 3,700 young people worldwide are preparing for their professional future with us as apprentices, students, or in internships.

Tomorrow we will look back on fiscal year 2024, but above all on our innovations and partnerships around the world.
has big ambitions. We want to reach many more people with our technologies and solutions, support healthcare providers even better in their daily fight against the most threatening diseases, and bring hope to where it is needed. This is also what our common purpose stands for: We pioneer breakthroughs in healthcare â€“ for everyone, everywhere, sustainably.

From 10:00 a.m. (CEST), you can follow the speeches of our Chairman of the Supervisory Board, Prof. Dr. Ralf P. Thomas, and myself. Please find the link to the broadcast in the comments.

UNICEFâ€™s motto â€œfor every childâ€ resonates very well with the purpose of Siemens Healthineers: â€œWe pioneer breakthroughs in healthcare. For everyone. Everywhere. Sustainably.â€ 

Not least for this reason, we have been working as partners for three years now to strengthen fragile healthcare systems in sub-Saharan Africa. The main objective is to expand networks for diagnostics in doctors offices. This stems from our fundamental belief that healthcare innovation must reach everyone, everywhere.

As a global medtech leader, we have both the capability and responsibility to improve childrenâ€™s lives worldwide. No single organization can do that alone: UNICEF's unparalleled reach and decades of experience in delivering healthcare solutions to underserved communities, combined with our technological expertise creates a powerful synergy that can drive meaningful change. Our experience with UNICEF has shown that partnerships between private sector companies and international organizations can bridge critical gaps in healthcare delivery.

Today we met in Berlin at Schloss Bellevue, the residence of the German Federal President Frank-Walter Steinmeier and First Lady Elke Buedenbender, patron of. The motto of the UNICEF New Year's Talk 2025 was â€œThe future is unwrittenâ€. We discussed how we can support the rights of the generations to come so that young people have the opportunity and skills to help shape society from an early age.

Many thanks to Elke Buedenbender, Alisha Kumar, Yolanda Tembo,, Burkhard Jung,,, Georg Graf Waldersee and.

Huge congratulations to Dorin Comaniciu on his election to the National Academy of Engineering Class of 2025! Dorin is being recognized for his contributions to diagnostic imaging and image-guided therapy, leading to better diagnosis and treatment for numerous patients. Election to the NAE is one of the highest professional honors for engineers in the U.S., and Dorin is truly deserving.

Since joiningover 9 years ago, he has made a tremendous impact on our growth strategy: from building a top-notch team of medtech pioneers and specialists and turning our Princeton research center into a powerhouse for AI in healthcare, to always pushing the boundaries of innovation. Heâ€™s also the kind of colleague you enjoy working withâ€”whether youâ€™re trading book recommendations, marveling over the latest breakthroughs on our supercomputer Sherlock, or debating the future of technology over coffee.

Well done, Dorin! Couldnâ€™t be happier for you.
